deliberation: Formulaic prophetic introduction (“this word came from YHWH”) and chronological notice are standard and function literally in context; I did not treat them as salient figurative language.

I checked the temple terminology and commands. Two clear figures emerge: (1) ‘all the cities of Judah who are coming to bow’ uses ‘cities’ for their inhabitants (metonymy); (2) ‘do not diminish/subtract a word’ treats the message as a measurable quantity (metaphorical/idiomatic).

instances.english_text: to [the inhabitants of] all the towns of Judah, who are coming to worship
target: the inhabitants of the Judean towns who come to worship
vehicle: “all the towns of Judah” spoken of as those who come to bow
ground: a city is closely identified with the people who live in it
posture: to address all Judeans comprehensively via their towns
instances.explanation: The verse grammatically treats the cities as those who ‘come to bow’, using the place (cities) to stand for their inhabitants.

target: Jeremiah’s communication of the divine message
vehicle: subtracting a measurable amount from a fixed quantity
ground: removing words from a message is like subtracting units from a total, leaving it incomplete
posture: to command complete and accurate transmission of the oracle
instances.explanation: The verb ‘to subtract’ is drawn from arithmetic/physical reduction and applied to words, picturing the message as a fixed quantity that must not be diminished.

deliberation: I examined ‘listen’, ‘turn back’, and ‘his evil way’. The key figurative complex is the metaphor of life-conduct as a ‘way’ or road from which one can turn back (repent).

instances.english_text: and turn back, each from their own evil way
target: each person’s pattern of behavior and moral choices
vehicle: a ‘way’ or road that a person walks on and can turn back from
ground: both a road and a lifestyle have a direction and can be reversed or changed
posture: call to abandon a destructive life-course and adopt a new one
instances.explanation: ‘Evil way’ conceptualizes a person’s behavior as a road, and ‘turn back’ as changing direction on that road, a standard biblical metaphor for repentance.

deliberation: Two expressions are potentially figurative: ‘listen to Me’ (obey) and especially ‘to walk in My Torah’. I count one primary metaphor here: obedience pictured as walking within God’s teaching.

instances.english_text: abiding by (literally, ‘to walk in’) the Teaching that I have set before you
target: Israel’s continuing obedience to God’s Torah
vehicle: walking along a path laid out before someone
ground: both walking a path and obeying a teaching involve ongoing movement within set boundaries laid out in front of you
posture: to stress that Torah requires a life-long course, not just a momentary decision
instances.explanation: Torah is pictured as a path set before the people, and obedience as ‘walking’ within it—an entrenched biblical metaphor for covenantal living.

deliberation: Beyond literal ‘sending’ of prophets, the phrase ‘rising early and sending’ (השׁכם ושלח) is Jeremiah’s characteristic idiom, anthropomorphically depicting God as a diligent human who gets up early to send messengers.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי שֹׁלֵחַ אֲלֵיכֶם וְהַשְׁכֵּם וְשָׁלֹחַ
instances.english_text: whom I have been sending to you persistently (literally, ‘rising early and sending’)
target: God’s persistent commissioning and dispatching of prophets to Judah
vehicle: a human master who gets up early in the morning to send out messengers
ground: rising early suggests eagerness, persistence, and priority, which parallel God’s repeated, urgent sending of prophets
posture: to underline God’s energetic efforts and thereby heighten Judah’s guilt for not listening
instances.explanation: God is portrayed in human terms as one who ‘rises early’ to send messengers—an idiomatic anthropomorphism emphasizing divine diligence in sending prophets.

deliberation: I found two distinct figures: (1) a simile likening the Jerusalem temple to Shiloh’s ruined sanctuary; (2) making ‘this city’ into ‘a curse’, where the city’s name becomes a proverbial malediction among the nations (metaphor/metonymy).

instances.english_text: then I will make this House like Shiloh
vehicle: the former sanctuary at Shiloh that was destroyed/abandoned
ground: both are central shrines that can lose divine favor and be desolated
posture: to warn that the current temple is not exempt from the fate of Shiloh
instances.explanation: The temple is explicitly compared to Shiloh’s ruined sanctuary, warning that it can likewise be abandoned and destroyed.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאֶת־הָעִיר הַזֹּאת אֶתֵּן לִקְלָלָה לְכֹל גּוֹיֵי הָאָרֶץ
instances.english_text: and I will make this city a curse for all the nations of earth
target: Jerusalem’s fate and reputation among the nations
vehicle: a curse used in maledictions (e.g., ‘may you be like X’)
ground: a destroyed city can become a byword invoked in curses, symbolizing extreme disaster
posture: to threaten that Jerusalem will serve as a notorious example of divine judgment
instances.explanation: The city (standing for its name and memory) is said to become ‘a curse’, i.e., a proverbial formula in international maledictions, using the city as a symbol of ruin.

deliberation: The verse simply narrates that priests, prophets, and people heard Jeremiah speaking in the temple; I see no non-literal or figurative expressions.
Despite the emphatic ‘die you shall die’ (infinitive absolute), the language describes literal seizure and a literal death threat; I do not treat the emphasis as figurative (e.g., not hyperbole).

Key expressions were evaluated: ‘House shall become like Shiloh’ repeats the simile from v.6; ‘city will be desolate without inhabitant’ can be literal devastation. Only the Shiloh comparison is clearly figurative here.

instances.english_text: that this House shall become like Shiloh
ground: both temples can be destroyed or abandoned because of covenant infidelity
posture: summary of Jeremiah’s threat as perceived by his accusers
instances.explanation: The opponents quote Jeremiah’s assertion that the temple will become ‘like Shiloh’, again invoking the earlier simile of a sanctuary reduced to ruin.

deliberation: This is a straightforward narrative of officials moving from the king’s house to the temple and sitting in the gate; the verbs ‘went up’ and ‘sat’ follow literal spatial and judicial usage. No figurative language identified.

Legal language (‘deserves the death penalty’, ‘prophesied against this city’) appears literal; ‘this city’ can naturally include both place and community without a marked figurative shift. No distinct figurative devices detected.

Jeremiah’s defense rehearses literal facts: YHWH sent him to prophesy against this house and this city, speaking all the words heard. The wording follows standard prophetic formula without a salient metaphor or idiom beyond normal usage.

Two figurative elements stand out: (1) ‘improve your ways’ again treats conduct as a ‘way’ or road; (2) ‘listen to the voice of YHWH’ uses ‘voice’ metonymically for his command and ‘listening’ for obedience.

instances.english_text: Therefore mend your ways and your acts
target: the people’s established patterns of life and behavior
vehicle: a ‘way’ or road that can be made good or straightened
ground: repairing a road and reforming behavior both involve removing harmful features and making a course suitable
posture: appeal to moral reform as condition for averting judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Ways’ presents their conduct as roads that can be ‘made good’, extending the common biblical metaphor of life as a path.

instances.english_text: and heed (literally, ‘listen to’) the voice of the ETERNAL your God
target: the people’s obedience to God’s will
vehicle: hearing someone’s literal voice and responding appropriately
ground: both obeying and listening involve attentive reception and appropriate response to what is said
posture: to frame obedience as receptive listening to God’s personal address
instances.explanation: God’s ‘voice’ stands for his commands, and ‘listening’ to it is the idiomatic way to speak of obedience—a metonymic and metaphorical framing of covenant loyalty.

deliberation: The key clause ‘I am in your hand’ is clearly metaphorical, depicting Jeremiah’s legal and physical vulnerability as being physically held in their hand.

instances.english_text: As for me, I am in your hands
target: Jeremiah’s dependence on the officials’ and people’s power over his fate
vehicle: an object or person physically held in someone’s hand
ground: what is in the hand is under one’s immediate control; Jeremiah’s life is under their decision-making power
posture: humble acknowledgment of their authority while maintaining his innocence elsewhere
instances.explanation: Jeremiah likens his situation to being in their physical hand, a conventional idiom for being under another’s control.

deliberation: I focused on ‘you are putting innocent blood upon yourselves and upon this city’. This uses ‘blood’ symbolically for guilt and ‘city’ metonymically for its community, picturing guilt as something placed upon them.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־דָם נָקִי אַתֶּם נֹתְנִים עֲלֵיכֶם וְאֶל־הָעִיר הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: for you and this city and its inhabitants will be guilty of shedding an innocent’s blood (literally, ‘you are putting innocent blood upon yourselves and upon this city’)
target: the moral and legal guilt incurred by unjustly killing Jeremiah
vehicle: innocent blood physically put upon persons or a city
ground: shed blood in biblical thought clings as a stain that requires atonement, paralleling guilt that remains upon a person or community
posture: to warn them that killing him will place a lasting, communal burden of guilt upon themselves
instances.explanation: ‘Innocent blood’ stands for the guilt of murder, and this guilt is pictured as something placed ‘upon’ them and their city, using blood as a metaphorical stain and the city as metonymy for its population.

deliberation: The officials and people straightforwardly declare Jeremiah lacks ‘death penalty’ because he spoke in God’s name; this is legal rather than figurative language. No metaphor or idiom beyond standard juridical phrasing.
This transitional narrative line (‘elders of the land arose and said…’) uses conventional verbs of standing and speaking with literal senses. No figurative language detected.

Micah’s old prophecy quoted here piles up three images of devastation: Zion plowed as a field, Jerusalem becoming heaps of ruins, and the Temple Mount turned into forest high places. These are three distinct but parallel metaphors of desolation.

instances.english_text: Zion shall be plowed as a field
target: Zion/Jerusalem as a built-up, fortified sacred hill
vehicle: an agricultural field being plowed flat for cultivation
ground: both razing a city and plowing a field involve leveling what was there and preparing it for something else
posture: to emphasize the totality of the coming demolition of the sacred city
instances.explanation: Zion, a built-up sacred hill, is depicted as turned into a plowed field, dramatizing the thorough leveling of its structures.

instances.english_text: Jerusalem shall become heaps of ruins
ground: both a ruined city and piles of rubble signify destruction and abandonment
posture: to underline the complete ruin of the city, not just partial damage
instances.explanation: The city is envisaged as nothing but ‘heaps’, a metaphor that collapses its identity into rubble to highlight its total ruin.

instances.english_text: and the Temple Mount [shall become] a shrine in the woods (literally, ‘high places of a forest’)
target: the Temple Mount as ordered, centralized worship site of YHWH
vehicle: a wooded hill with scattered ‘high places’
ground: an abandoned temple area and a forested hill with high places both lack structured, centralized worship and appear chaotic and profane
posture: to depict reversal from organized temple worship to desolate, quasi-pagan landscape
instances.explanation: The Temple Mount is envisioned as turning into forest ‘high places’, merging imagery of abandonment, overgrowth, and illicit shrines to show religious collapse.

deliberation: Two expressions are figurative: (1) ‘he entreated the face of YHWH’ personifies God and uses ‘face’ as metonymy for presence/favor; (2) ‘we are doing great evil upon our own souls’ pictures their intended action as self-inflicted harm on their own lives.

instances.english_text: and he implored (literally, ‘entreated the face of’) GOD
target: Hezekiah’s act of praying earnestly to God
vehicle: seeking an audience with someone’s face/presence to win favor
ground: both prayer and pleading before a human superior involve approaching a presence and seeking favorable response
posture: to portray Hezekiah as humbly and personally appealing to God’s favor
instances.explanation: God is described as having a ‘face’ that can be entreated; the phrase uses human imagery for God’s presence and favor and functions as an idiom for fervent prayer.

instances.english_text: We are about to do great injury to ourselves (literally, ‘we are doing great evil upon our souls/lives’)
target: the spiritual and existential harm they will bring on themselves by killing Jeremiah
ground: both harming oneself physically and committing grave sin against one’s own life lead to one’s own ruin
posture: to warn themselves that opposing the prophet is ultimately suicidal
instances.explanation: Their contemplated action is pictured as doing ‘great evil’ upon their own lives, an idiomatic metaphor for bringing ruin down on themselves.

deliberation: This verse introduces Uriah and states that he prophesied against the city and the land like Jeremiah. The language is straightforward and mirrors earlier literal descriptions of prophecy. No distinct figurative expressions identified.
The narrative describes hearing, fearing, fleeing, and going to Egypt. These are ordinary physical and emotional actions; no metaphors or idioms beyond literal usage.
Jehoiakim ‘sent men to Egypt’; this is a literal political action, not metaphorical ‘sending’. No figurative language detected.

Uriah is brought back, struck with the sword, and his body thrown into common graves. Given the narrative context, ‘struck with the sword’ describes his actual execution instrumentally and is not functioning as a separate idiom. No clear figurative expressions isolated.
The phrase ‘the hand of Ahikam was with Jeremiah’ is figurative: ‘hand’ stands for active power/help, and ‘being with’ expresses protective support, an idiomatic metaphor/metonymy for patronage.

instances.hebrew_text: אַךְ יַד אֲחִיקָם בֶּן־שָׁפָן הָיְתָה אֶת־יִרְמְיָהוּ
instances.english_text: However, the hand of Ahikam son of Shaphan was with Jeremiah
target: Ahikam’s protective influence and active support for Jeremiah
vehicle: a physical hand being ‘with’ someone, able to help or shield
hand as instrument of action and power
ground: hands perform actions and exercise power; a ‘hand with’ someone suggests active backing and protection
posture: to credit Ahikam with decisive protective action that saved Jeremiah
instances.explanation: ‘Hand’ functions metonymically for Ahikam’s power and agency, and the idiom ‘his hand was with Jeremiah’ metaphorically portrays his active protection and support.
